text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised text for IRM 8.19.2, Managers/TEFRA Resources.
Updated IRM 8.19.2.4.1 to incorporate Interim Guidance AP-08-0415-0002, Mandatory Appeals TEFRA Team (ATT) Referrals, to provide guidance on use of ATT services.
Updated IRM 8.19.2.8.1 and IRM 8.19.2.8.2 to incorporate IG AP-08-0714-004, Implementation of the Appeals Judicial Approach and Culture (AJAC) Project Examination and General Matters - Phase 2
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

IRM 8.19.2 dated October 1, 2013 is superseded. Incorporated Interim Guidance Memorandum AP-08-0714- 004, Implementation of the Appeals Judicial Approach and Culture (AJAC) Project, Examination and General Matters - Phase 2 changes, which was issued July 2, 2014, and AP-08-0415-0002, Mandatory Appeals TEFRA Team (ATT) Referrals, which was issued April 7, 2015, into this IRM
All Appeals employees working with TEFRA partnership returns and TEFRA partners.
Table of Contents

) This section provides guidelines for managers and resources for TEFRA cases. a. Use this section of the Handbook to clarify the responsibilities of managers and TEFRA resource persons. b. Be alert to problems that may have national implications and bring them the attention of the Appeals Technical Specialist(s) for TEFRA. (

) The Appeals TEFRA Team (ATT) and TEFRA Technical Specialists serve as the resource persons for managers and all other Appeals employees. They should know and understand the responsibilities for all TEFRA duties within Appeals office, including the procedures in this section relating only to the manager. (
) The guidelines in this Handbook are specifically for pass-thru entity cases and especially for TEFRA cases. They supplement the general information in other parts of the Appeals IRM.
manager. (

) The guidelines in this Handbook are specifically for pass-thru entity cases especially for TEFRA cases. They supplement the general information in parts of the Appeals IRM. Caution: Users are cautioned to seek guidance from the Appeals Technical cialist(s) for TEFRA if questions of authority arise. (
) The list of TEFRA resource persons is found on the Appeals TEFRA (

) All guidance in this section concerning the Campus TEFRA Functions is for cases controlled on the Partnership Control System (PCS). The CTFs only work with key cases and partners controlled on the PCS. (
) TEFRA cases are worked at the key case level. The Appeals office has diction over settlement of the partnership issues and the penalties and items. (

) The partner returns which are not Coordinated Industry Case (CIC) corpora- tions, Joint Committee or corporate specialty cases will remain in the TEFRA Function (CTF). The CTF is responsible for statute control, settlements and notices, and making assessments for the PCS-linked cases which are not Coordinated Industry Case (CIC) corporations, Joint Committee or corporate specialty cases. The CTF will generally handle questions about computations for PCS linked partner cases which are not ordinated Industry Case (CIC) corporations, Joint Committee or corporate specialty cases. (

) CIC corporation partner cases will be suspended and controlled in the area/ territory where the returns were examined unless Appeals has jurisdiction of the return. a. The tax computations and assessments are the responsibility of the partner’s area/territory or the Appeals office, whichever has jurisdiction the CIC partner case. (

) Joint Committee cases and other corporate specialty partner cases will be handled in the same manner as the CIC corporation partner cases. Other corporate specialty cases are the following: a. Forms
with letters after the
other than A, S, or X (e.g., for Life Insurance companies) b. Cases with an activity code of
or higher. Internal Revenue Manual
Caution: Users are cautioned to seek guidance from the Appeals Technical Spe- cialist(s) for TEFRA if questions of authority arise.
TEFRA cases are worked at the key case level. The Appeals office has juris- diction over settlement of the partnership issues and the penalties and affected
(10-01-2013) Jurisdiction of TEFRA Cases
CIC corporation partner cases will be suspended and controlled in the area/ territory where the returns were examined unless Appeals has jurisdiction of
Appeals Pass-Through Entity (

) Penalties and affected item issues should generally be considered with the case. Under the key case concept, the focus at the key Appeals office be the partnership issues and related penalties and affected items. Caution: Prior to the Taxpayer Relief Act of

, penalties related to a TEFRA entity were considered at the partner level. Penalties were imposed in a separate deficiency proceeding after the completion of the unified entity proceeding. The Taxpayer Relief Act of

provides that the ity of any penalty that relates to an adjustment to a partnership item will be determined in the partnership level proceeding. Whether or not penalties are applicable will be determined in the partnership level pro- ceeding for partnership tax years ending after August
(see IRM

) Affected items may be considered after the partnership adjustments The TEFRA program cannot be effectively administered unless affected are considered when the key case is evaluated. In addition, partners should given an opportunity to settle affected item issues as early as possible. The appeals officer (AO) must evaluate affected item issues at the partnership and attempt to resolve them at that time. (

) If affected item issues are unagreed when the partnership administrative pro- ceeding concludes, and a partner protests or petitions the affected item Appeals will consider each partner case separately. This eliminates the benefits of a unified proceeding. While some partners will require a separate determination at the partner level, the key AO should always evaluate the overall merits of the affected item issues at the partnership level. Also see
, Settlement of Penalty and Affected Item Issues. (
) For partnership tax years ending after August

, if the penalty is unagreed when the partnership administrative proceeding concludes, will issue a Notice of Final Partnership Administrative Adjustment (FPAA) to address the penalty at the partnership level. Also see IRM

, ment of Penalty and Affected Item Issues. a. Partners who wish to contest penalties on the basis of partnership level defenses must contest penalties as a part of the partnership proceeding. b. Partners who wish to contest penalties on the basis of partner level defenses, such as good faith and reasonable cause, must contest the penalties by filing a refund claim after the penalties are assessed. See IRC
) When an AO evaluating penalty issues on a key case (e.g., overvaluation) becomes aware that a related IRC

penalty for promoting an abusive shelter was asserted, the AO should contact the examiner to advise of the proposed key case penalty settlement, particularly if the proposal is a full cession by the Government. (
) The duties of the ATM and ATT will overlap at times and may require some coordination. Team
8.19 Appeals Pass-Through Entity Handbook

a. Partners who wish to contest penalties on the basis of partnership level defenses must contest penalties as a part of the partnership b. Partners who wish to contest penalties on the basis of partner level defenses, such as good faith and reasonable cause, must contest the penalties by filing a refund claim after the penalties are assessed. See IRC

a. Identify and resolve TEFRA problems. b. If a TEFRA key case is in local APS for assignment and bypassed Niguel APS and the ATT, then forward the case to Laguna Niguel APS. c. Assign the appropriate grade to the key case. d. Assign new TEFRA workunits to the appropriate AO. e. Understand the statute, the IRM on TEFRA cases (both key cases and partner returns), and the ATT role in TEFRA cases. f. Review cases for technical and procedural accuracy. g. Ensure TEFRA settlements meet the guidelines for settling cases. h. Execute settlement agreement forms. i. Sign FPAA letters.

i. Sign FPAA letters. Note: The responsibility for some of these duties can overlap into the ATT duties. The responsibility for executing agreement forms remains with the ATM. ATM will sign FPAA letters when the ATT is not used. When the ATT is the ATM of the ATT will sign the FPAA letters. (

) Review work units prior to assignment to ensure the case is assigned to the appropriate AO. Because of the procedural difficulties and length of time required to close a TEFRA case, exercise care when assigning TEFRA (

) An acknowledgement letter will be sent to the TMP and partners who have filed protests or petitions. The ATM or his/her designee will generate and the acknowledgment letter. The acknowledgment letter procedures in IRM
apply to these cases. (
) Although TEFRA cases have adjustments, not deficiencies, these cases up a large part of the Appeals inventory and typically involve large dollar amounts. (
) Since the partner cases are not available to the Appeals office, the formula shown in IRM Exhibit
is used to compute the estimated TEFRA ficiency.” The formula is also used to compute the estimated revised dollars closing. However, at closing use line
, Form
-A, prepared by Appeals line
of the formula. Use the highest individual tax rate for joint filers as shown in IRM Exhibit
for both proposed and revised dollars less of who the specific investors may be. (

) When the case is initially assigned to the ATT, the TEFRA AO will compute estimated proposed deficiency and validate it on ACDS. If the case is not initially assigned to the ATT (it went to local APS without going through Niguel APS) then the field AO assigned to the case must compute the estimated deficiency and validate ACDS.
Appeals Pass-Through Entity (
) When the case is closed, the field AO should compute the revised and enter it on Form
The TEFRA AO will verify it and instruct APS to update it, if needed. Revised dollars are entered on ACDS only when the TEFRA key case is closed. (
) The ATM will need to determine the correct grade of each case using the grading guidelines in IRM
and IRM Exhibit
, IRM
, Grading and IRM
. Generally, grade the cases based upon the complexity the issues. (
) Since the key case will include the estimated proposed tax deficiency for all investors, ACDS will automatically record the case at a grade
or
The ATM must then determine the correct grade and promptly advise APS. (
) The statute of limitations must be protected for both key cases and partner cases. of Limitations for (
) For a complete discussion on the statutory period of limitation, see IRM Cases
and IRM
) The statute of limitations for assessment is generally three years from the extended due date of the partnership return or the date filed, whichever is Case later. (

) This statute may be extended by mutual agreement. However, Chief office does not recommend allowing a representative to sign any legally cant documents (consents) on behalf of the TMP. It is therefore that all consents be signed by the TMP unless the requirements of Treas.
are met for a non-TMP authorized by the partnership. See
, When a non-TMP Executes Consents. (

) Copies of consents secured from either a TEFRA partnership or a partner TEFRA key case should be sent to both the Ogden and Brookhaven CTFs. Instructions for sending consents to the CTFs are found on the Appeals TEFRA website. Note: A TEFRA key case should not be accepted in Appeals unless there are least
(or at least
for cases being returned from Compliance after their consideration of a new issue or new information) days remaining on statute. (

) The statute on the partner’s return is controlled by the statute on the partnership until the partnership items are resolved. At that time, the Case statute becomes the one-year assessment period provided by IRC
(d) IRC

and IRM

Copies of TEFRA partner consents extending a TEFRA statute should be sent to both CTFs by the AO. See IRM 8.19.2.8.1.
Note: A TEFRA partner case should not be accepted in Appeals unless there are at least 365 (or at least 180 for cases being returned from Compliance after

their consideration of a new issue or new information) days remaining on all one-year statute dates (one-year assessment dates) for the partner if the investor is a CIC corporation, a Joint Committee case or an other corporate specialty case. Compliance is responsible for computing and assessing the tax from all TEFRA linkages which have a live one-year statute date before the case reaches Appeals for CIC corporation, Joint Committee and corporate specialty cases. The ATM has discretion whether to accept a partner case with a live one-year statute date or to return the case to Com- pliance for computation and assessment of the live one-year statute date before returning the case to Appeals for consideration of the non-TEFRA issues. See IRM
for an explanation of other corporate specialty cases.

their consideration of a new issue or new information) days remaining on one-year statute dates (one-year assessment dates) for the partner if the investor is a CIC corporation, a Joint Committee case or an other specialty case. The ATM has discretion whether to accept a partner case with a live one-year statute date or to return the case to pliance for computation and assessment of the live one-year statute date before returning the case to Appeals for consideration of the non-TEFRA issues. See IRM 8.19.6.2 for an explanation of other corporate specialty cases.

partner case with a live one-year statute date or to return the case to pliance for computation and assessment of the live one-year statute date before returning the case to Appeals for consideration of the non-TEFRA issues. See IRM
for an explanation of other corporate specialty cases. (
) Review all cases to identify systemic or procedural problems that need to considered for corrective action. Make corrections timely at the local level if possible. (
) Timely apprise the area office and/or Appeals Technical Specialist(s) for TEFRA of the facts and circumstances when the situation requires their in- volvement. (

) The manager must review and approve all settlements before they are directly to the partners or to the CTF for subsequent mailing to the This is especially important because of the consistent agreement the unified proceedings. If just one partner agreement is erroneously the Service may be bound to the same settlement for all unagreed (

) CTF processing is an integral part of any partnership settlement. the manager should ensure that processing instructions to the CTF are complete and accurate and that the CTF has the capability to process the settlement. (

) Due to the unique statutory requirements of TEFRA, consider certain areas when settling partnership cases. a. Confidential information unique to one partner must not be disclosed another partner or to the TMP. b. Particular care is required when penalty or affected item issues are considered. (

) Cash out-of-pocket settlements based on a partner’s cash investment are generally not compatible with the concept of a unified proceeding because the verification problem. A settlement agreement based on cash would the verification of the specific dollar amount of cash paid by every partner. (
) If a partner’s cash contribution percentage does not equal his/her profit and loss percentage, a cash out-of-pocket settlement may create consistency problems. (
) Avoid this problem by offering all partners their pro-rata share of a specific dollar amount for settlement purposes.
Review all cases to identify systemic or procedural problems that need to be considered for corrective action. Make corrections timely at the local level if
Timely apprise the area office and/or Appeals Technical Specialist(s) for TEFRA of the facts and circumstances when the situation requires their
Appeals Pass-Through Entity (

) Consider settlements regarding the correct allocation of distributions only if partners agree to the allocation. The allocation of key case level items of all partners must be fully disclosed on the schedule of adjustments included all partners’ agreement forms. Note: Disclose a partners’ partner-level item adjustments only to the specific partner. (

) This is a whipsaw issue requiring agreement by all parties. If the has an effect on basis, reflect the corrected basis amounts on the Form (TEFRA Partners’ Shares of Income) sent to the CTF for computations. (
) Refer to IRM
, for more information on allocation issues and Exhibit
and IRM Exhibit
for samples of the schedule of adjustments for allocation issues. (
) Partner level elements of penalties and affected item issues should be ered with the partnership case. (

) The AO should review the examiner’s affected item report and determine a recommended settlement position on the partner level elements of penalties affected items based upon the activities at the partnership level. This will include the overvaluation of assets. (

) The AO should prepare an abbreviated affected item appeals case memo (ACM) for the recommended settlement position. A copy of the abbreviated affected item ACM will be included with the closing package to the key CTF. See Exhibit
for a sample affected item ACM. (

) Generally, any additional facts which are based on activities at the partner level will only be considered in evaluating a partner’s individual case after partnership proceeding has been completed (but see (
) below): a. For partnership tax years ending after August

, penalties are mined at the partnership level. Any penalties determined will be and the partner must file a refund claim after the penalties are and paid, at which time additional facts unique to that partner partner reasonable cause and good faith defenses to a penalty) may presented. b. For affected items, the partner will receive a notice of deficiency or affected item report at which time additional facts unique to that partner may be presented. (
) For partnership tax years ending after August

, if the number of partners is relatively small (generally five or fewer), the AO may consider partner level defenses to a penalty as part of the consideration of the ship case. If a settlement is reached, Form
-LT(AD) will be used. On the Schedule of Adjustments page of the Form

–LT(AD), partnership level penalties (including percentages) will be shown in Part I and partner level defenses to these penalties (including percentages) will be shown in Part II. See example of a Form
-LT(AD) Schedule of Adjustments page in
Example: If a partnership level accuracy penalty is determined to be
%, it will shown in Part I. If after considering a partner level defense to the

8.19.2.10.3 (10-01-2013) Penalty and Affected Item Issues
For partnership tax years ending after August

, if the number of partners is relatively small (generally five or fewer), the AO may consider partner level defenses to a penalty as part of the consideration of the partner- ship case. If a settlement is reached, Form
-LT(AD) will be used. On the Schedule of Adjustments page of the Form

–LT(AD), partnership level penalties (including percentages) will be shown in Part I and partner level defenses to these penalties (including percentages) will be shown in Part II. See example of a Form
-LT(AD) Schedule of Adjustments page in Exhibit
Example: If a partnership level accuracy penalty is determined to be 20%, it will be shown in Part I. If after considering a partner level defense to the
penalty it is determined that the penalty will be reduced to 10% due to reasonable cause, it will be shown in Part II.

reasonable cause, it will be shown in Part II. Caution: It is very important that any reduction of a partnership level penalty considering a partner level defense be shown in Part II. Partner level defenses are not partnership items and are therefore not subject to a request for consistent settlement. If a partner level penalty is shown in Part I, it would be subject to a request for consistent settlement by any other partners (including those that did not establish reasonable such as a promoter). (
) For partnership tax years ending after August

, if the penalty is unagreed when the partnership proceeding concludes, Appeals will issue a Notice of Final Partnership Administrative Adjustment (FPAA) to address the penalty at the partnership level. a. Partners who wish to contest penalties on the basis of partnership level defenses must contest them as a part of the partnership proceeding. b. Partners who wish to contest penalties on the basis of partner level defenses, such as good faith and reasonable cause, must contest the penalties by filing a refund claim after the penalties are assessed and paid. See IRC
) In evaluating penalty issues on a partnership case (e.g., overvaluation), you become aware that an IRC

penalty for promoting an abusive tax shelter was asserted, contact the examiner to advise of the proposed ship case penalty settlement, particularly if the proposal is a full concession the Government (

) Avoid closing agreements in settlements on TEFRA key cases whenever possible. On the date they are executed by the Service these agreements convert partnership items to nonpartnership items for any future years that settled, triggering a one-year assessment period under IRC
(f) for years, unless it is a partial agreement. See IRC
) In the event that closing agreements are determined to be necessary on a given case, consider the following provisions: a. A closing agreement for a TEFRA partnership is made under the of IRC
(c) and IRC
Both sections should be cited in the paragraph of the closing agreement as follows: “Under sections
(c) and

of the Internal Revenue Code er’s name, address and taxpayer identification number] (the and the Commissioner of Internal Revenue make the following closing agreement:” b. -PT(AD) for an example of this language. d. For all cases including affected items – Include waiver language which allows any amount resulting from any change to affected items to be assessed. See Form
-LT(AD) for an example of this language. The Taxpayer Relief Act of

It is very important that any reduction of a partnership level penalty after considering a partner level defense be shown in Part II. Partner level defenses are not partnership items and are therefore not subject to a request for consistent settlement. If a partner level penalty is shown in Part I, it would be subject to a request for consistent settlement by any other partners (including those that did not establish reasonable cause, such as a promoter).

Partners who wish to contest penalties on the basis of partnership defenses must contest them as a part of the partnership proceeding. Partners who wish to contest penalties on the basis of partner level defenses, such as good faith and reasonable cause, must contest the penalties by filing a refund claim after the penalties are assessed and paid. penalties for partnership tax years ending after August
The language in Forms
-PT(AD) and
-LT(AD) reflect the new law. For closing agreements that finalize all partnership level adjustments – Include language to clarify that the minimum one-year assessment period under IRC
(f) will not begin to run until the closing agreement is executed for the Commissioner. The following language may be used.

“This agreement will not become effective or final until this agreement form is returned to the Commissioner of Internal Revenue and is signed on his or her behalf. The minimum one year extension of the period of limitations on under Internal Revenue Code Section 6229(f) will not begin to run until the date Commissioner’s representative signs this form on the Commissioner’s behalf.”

“This partial agreement becomes effective upon execution by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue or his delegate. It does not settle all of the partnership items. The remaining unsettled partnership items as well as any unsettled penalty, addition to tax, or additional amount that relates to an adjustment to a partnership item will remain subject to determination under the partnership-level administrative and judicial procedures. The period of limitations for assessing any tax attributable to the settled items shall be determined as if such agreement had not been entered into. To the extent this paragraph conflicts with any other paragraph in this agreement, this paragraph controls.”
Note: Penalties are not “partnership items.”
Note: If the issues in a partial agreement become complex or involve narily large amounts, consider using a closing agreement.

A closing agreement with terms affecting subsequent years is an effective settle- ment agreement pursuant to IRC 6231(b)(1)(C) which removes that partner and those partnership items immediately from the TEFRA partnership provisions, before the future year commences at least as to the settled items.
The unified partnership proceedings involve logistics problems in securing and processing settlement agreements for every partner. Even in those situations where the TMP may bind non
notice partners or where a pass

thru partner may bind indirect partners, every partner’s return must be controlled by the Campus TEFRA Function in order to make the computational adjustments so that assessments or refunds can be made. This is a cumbersome and time
consuming procedure, particularly where the key case has partnerships as investors.

page (

) While the only criteria on which a settlement may be based are the facts, and hazards of litigation, the settlement should be structured to simplify its plication to the partners’ returns to the extent possible. (

) Settlements that require follow-up action in future years may inadvertently prejudice an examination of the subsequent years. To avoid this situation, AO should determine whether the later affected years are currently under ex- amination. If so, the AO should discuss the settlement of the current years the examiner. (

) If the later years are not under examination, the AO should secure copies of the returns for the affected years and ascertain that the settlement will not prejudice an examination of subsequent years. The AO should also notify Compliance of any follow-up action required as a result of the settlement by using Form

8.19 Appeals Pass-Through Entity

Appeals Pass-Through Entity leader or ATM deems it necessary to extend the one-year statute date to the expense of time consuming computations while the investor case is in Appeals for non-TEFRA consideration, the AO will encourage an advance payment of tax. See IRM

Caution: Do not disclose to the TMP addresses of partners, spouse’s names the partner filed a joint return. Check with your local Disclosure
) Delegation Order No.

authorizes appropriate officials to sign notices such as FPAAs and settlement agreements. This authority for executing settlement agreements has been extended to AOs in the CTFs but not as to their respec- tive cases. Appeals settlement agreements may be executed by Revenue Agents GS-
and above in the CTFs. (
) The full authority within Appeals to sign FPAAs and settlement agreements as well as to designate a TMP has been delegated to ATMs, and to appeals team case leaders as to their respective cases. (
) Refer to Delegation Order Number
, IRM
, for settlement authority for your case.
(10-01-2013) Settlement Authority
) The CTFs have the ability to mail computer generated NBAPs,

) The key case CTF will notify the TMP of settlement agreements for both docketed and docketed key cases regardless of whether the settlement TMP of agreement is executed in the CTF or the Appeals office. However, the CTF not provide the Tax Court Rule

) In the rare instance when Appeals must notify the TMP of a settlement not requiring Rule

(c) notification (such as for cases not controlled on PCS) follow these guidelines: a. Do not give the TMP copies of executed settlement agreements since it may be a disclosure problem to provide the TMP with the new address an investor, the name of the investor’s spouse, or whether the investor filed a joint return, without a court order. b. Provide the TMP a list of the names of the agreed partners and a copy the schedule of adjustments. c. If the settlement agreement is a Form

-LT(AD) because of the potential disclosure problem. d. If the AO is responsible for notifying the TMP of a settlement, which is a Rule
